results.title: Taylor Swift, Caught Between Yesterday and Tomorrow on ‘Midnights’
results.abstract: The singer-songwriter’s 10th studio album returns to the pop sound she left in 2019, and explores a familiar subject: how she is perceived, and how she perceives herself.

multimedia.caption: Taylor Swift’s “Midnights” recalls the sound of “Lover,” the album she put out in 2019 before two surprise releases — “Folklore” and “Evermore” — in 2020.
Taylor Swift’s “Midnights” recalls the sound of “Lover,” the album she put out in 2019 before two surprise releases — “Folklore” and “Evermore” — in 2020.
Taylor Swift’s “Midnights” recalls the sound of “Lover,” the album she put out in 2019 before two surprise releases — “Folklore” and “Evermore” — in 2020.

results.title: The Clock Strikes: Time for Taylor Swift’s New LP, ‘Midnights’
results.abstract: The singer-songwriter’s 10th studio album is a return to the pop pipeline, with production from her longtime collaborator Jack Antonoff.

multimedia.caption: Taylor Swift announced the 13-track “Midnights” two months ago, calling it “the story of 13 sleepless nights scattered throughout my life.”
Taylor Swift announced the 13-track “Midnights” two months ago, calling it “the story of 13 sleepless nights scattered throughout my life.”

results.title: ‘Everything Everywhere,’ All Through Awards Season?
results.abstract: At a screening filled with Oscar voters, Michelle Yeoh, Ke Huy Quan and the directors marveled at the way their quirky film has struck a chord.

multimedia.caption: The cast and crew at the Los Angeles screening on Tuesday night, including Michelle Yeoh, in yellow, the directors Daniel Scheinert and Daniel Kwan behind and in front of her, and Ke Huy Quan, second from right in the middle row.

results.title: An Iranian Exile Channels Her Trauma Into Film
results.abstract: Zar Amir Ebrahimi, who had to flee Iran after an intimate tape was leaked, has been transfixed by the protests erupting there as her film “Holy Spider” is released in the U.S.

multimedia.copyright: Elliott Verdier for The New York Times
Elliott Verdier for The New York Times

results.title: EJ Hill Wants to Take You on a Ride
results.abstract: Some things about life — and America — “you have to feel in your gut,” this artist says. So he’s building a roller coaster inside a museum.

multimedia.caption: The artist EJ Hill and his working roller coaster named “Brava!” mid-assembly at Mass MoCA in North Adams, Mass.
multimedia.copyright: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times

results.title: How George Clooney and Julia Roberts Quietly Became the Tracy-Hepburn of Our Time
results.abstract: “Ticket to Paradise” and other team-ups take advantage of their onscreen glamour and stellar chemistry and their offscreen affection for one another.

multimedia.caption: They each bring movie-star qualities in addition to their onscreen chemistry.
They each bring movie-star qualities in addition to their onscreen chemistry.

results.title: ‘Glengarry Glen Ross’ and ‘Reservoir Dogs’ at 30: Men Talking
results.abstract: These dramas, both known for distinctive (and salty) dialogue, didn’t make much of a box office impression in 1992. But their influence is still being felt.

multimedia.caption: From left, Quentin Tarantino, Michael Madsen, Edward Bunker and Steve Buscemi in “Reservoir Dogs.”
From left, Quentin Tarantino, Michael Madsen, Edward Bunker and Steve Buscemi in “Reservoir Dogs.”

results.title: How the Philharmonic’s New Home Sounds, From Any Seat
results.abstract: After a major renovation, the acoustics throughout David Geffen Hall are strikingly consistent — but complicated.

multimedia.caption: Jaap van Zweden leading the New York Philharmonic in its second subscription program at the new David Geffen Hall, a space the orchestra is audibly settling into.

results.title: Tammy Faye Bakker and Televangelism Make the Jump to the London Stage
results.abstract: Fifteen years after her death, the peaks and valleys of Tammy Faye’s life, including the extravagance, the betrayal and her unwavering love of God, are explored in a new musical.

multimedia.caption: Katie Brayben, who plays the title role in “Tammy Faye,” in a rehearsal at the Almeida Theater in London in September. The show has been in the works for about a decade.

results.title: ‘Back to the Future’ Musical to Open on Broadway Next Summer
results.abstract: The show, now in London, has a creative team that combines veterans of the film with some Broadway stalwarts. Performances will begin on June 30.

results.title: More Money Can Mean More Museums, Just Look at Florida
results.abstract: Especially on the coasts of the state, the wealthy are increasingly choosing to start their own museums rather than house their collections in someone else’s.

results.title: Meret Oppenheim, a Rebel of Surrealist Art, Wanted the Last Word
results.abstract: She planned her own retrospective before her death. A third of her suggestions got in, including the furry tea set that made her name.

multimedia.caption: The artist Meret Oppenheim, seen here with her 1975 work “Six Clouds on a Bridge” in 1982. She was known for her playful unpredictability and unwillingness to be defined by others.

results.title: Out of Obscurity, Lynne Drexler’s Abstract Paintings Fetch Millions
results.abstract: After a derailed career, Ms. Drexler became a “hermit” painter on an island. Decades later, piqued public interest can earn her work seven figures.

multimedia.caption: The artist Lynne Drexler, shown here in a portrait from 1960, is attracting attention after years in relative obscurity.
The artist Lynne Drexler, shown here in a portrait from 1960, is attracting attention after years in relative obscurity.

results.title: A Minnesota Exhibit Framed Around Longing for Home
results.abstract: In a show that ranges from Northern California to Laos, the Hmong American artist Pao Houa Her explores landscape, making a living and a peculiar kind of paradise.

multimedia.caption: “Pao Houa Her: Paj qaum ntuj/Flowers of the Sky,” runs at the Walker Art Center through Jan. 22.
“Pao Houa Her: Paj qaum ntuj/Flowers of the Sky,” runs at the Walker Art Center through Jan. 22.

results.abstract: The 24-year-old “internet kid” from Liverpool melds contemporary iconography with figurative works of art.

results.title: ‘A Little Life’ Review: A Collage of Unrelenting Torment
results.abstract: Hanya Yanagihara’s best-selling novel comes to the BAM stage, and raises the question: How much suffering can the protagonist (and the audience) endure?

results.title: An Ode to the Public Library
results.abstract: In search of a quiet space, an artist encounters the vibrancy of the New York Public Library.

results.title: Lucy Simon, Singer and Broadway Composer, Dies at 82
results.abstract: She and her sister Carly Simon were a folk duo in the 1960s. Years later, she wrote the Tony-nominated music for “The Secret Garden.”

multimedia.caption: Lucy Simon in 1982. Her younger sister, Carly, became a best-selling pop star after their folk-duo days, and her older sister, Joanna, was an opera singer. Joanna died a day before Lucy’s death.
Lucy Simon in 1982. Her younger sister, Carly, became a best-selling pop star after their folk-duo days, and her older sister, Joanna, was an opera singer. Joanna died a day before Lucy’s death.
Lucy Simon in 1982. Her younger sister, Carly, became a best-selling pop star after their folk-duo days, and her older sister, Joanna, was an opera singer. Joanna died a day before Lucy’s death.

results.title: Joanna Simon, Opera Singer from Famously Musical Family, Dies at 85
results.abstract: A renowned mezzo-soprano, she grew up alongside her younger sisters, Carly and Lucy, both of whom became singer-songwriters.

multimedia.caption: Joanna Simon performing at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall in 1999. She was one of the best-known American opera singers to emerge in the 1960s.
Joanna Simon performing at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall in 1999. She was one of the best-known American opera singers to emerge in the 1960s.
Joanna Simon performing at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall in 1999. She was one of the best-known American opera singers to emerge in the 1960s.

results.title: In a Musical About Penicillin’s Inventor, Superbugs Take Center Stage
results.abstract: “The Mold That Changed the World” traces the life of the inventor of penicillin and offers a message: Don’t take antibiotics unless you really need them.
des_facet: The Mold That Changed the World (Play)

multimedia.caption: Jeremy Rose stars as Alexander Fleming, the physician who invented penicillin, in the musical “The Mold That Changed the World.”

results.title: ‘The African Desperate’ Expands the Movies’ Narrow View of the Art World
results.abstract: Most films set adjacent to studios and galleries lampoon unfathomable pretension, but Martine Syms takes a more nuanced approached in her look at art schools.

multimedia.caption: Diamond Stingily as a Master of Fine Arts student in “The African Desperate,” directed by Martine Syms. Both the star and director are artists.
Diamond Stingily as a Master of Fine Arts student in “The African Desperate,” directed by Martine Syms. Both the star and director are artists.

results.title: How to Be Medea? Summon Your Anger and Despair, and Hit the Gym.
results.abstract: Sondra Radvanovsky has taken on one of opera’s most grueling roles. “You can’t just act it,” she said. “You really have to live it.”

multimedia.caption: The soprano Sondra Radvanovsky did boxing sessions with a trainer to build stamina and strength for singing the title role in “Medea” at the Metropolitan Opera.
multimedia.copyright: George Etheredge for The New York Times

results.title: Lenny Lipton, ‘Puff the Magic Dragon’ Lyricist and 3-D Film Pioneer, 82, Dies
results.abstract: He used the royalties earned from the hit folk song, based on a poem he wrote in college, to fund decades of research into stereoscopic projection.

multimedia.caption: Lenny Lipton in 2008. He called the money he got from “Puff the Magic Dragon” his “MacArthur ‘genius’ grant,” allowing to leave his job, move to California and start a career in 3-D films.
Lenny Lipton in 2008. He called the money he got from “Puff the Magic Dragon” his “MacArthur ‘genius’ grant,” allowing to leave his job, move to California and start a career in 3-D films.

results.title: In London, Massed Human Misery and Communal Revelations

results.title: Prints Make Themselves Seen (and Heard) Again
